headline: President Trump attacks Dems over their impeachment obsession
subHeadline: Trump ends meeting with top Democrats after Nancy Pelosi accused him of committing a 'cover-up'; reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everybody. I'm Jesse Waters along with Emily Compagno, Juan Williams, Dana Perino, and Greg. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is “The Five.” It's a full blown battle over impeachment playing out in Washington D.C., President Trump blasting Democrats for their latest conspiratorial attacks. He was supposed to be with Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi this morning to talk about infrastructure. But right before Pelosi said this.

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF.
utterances.sentences: It was a very positive meeting of respectful sharing of ideas. Would you believe that it's important for -- to follow the facts? We believe that no one is above the law, including the President of the United States. And we believe that the President of the United States is engaged in a cover-up. In a cover-up, and that was the nation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: After that stunt, Trump decided to blow up the meeting by calling out Schumer and Pelosi to their faces and walked away. He then headed to the Rose Garden equipped with a classic Trump visual where he laid into Democrats.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: All of a sudden I hear last night they're going to have a meeting right before this meeting to talk about the I-word. The I-word. Instead of walking in happily into a meeting, I walk in to look at people that have just said that I was doing a cover-up. I don't do cover-ups.  I told Senator Schumer, Speaker Pelosi, I want to do infrastructure. But you know what? You can't do it under these circumstances. So get these phony investigations over with.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Schumer and Pelosi responding by trying to spin the meeting.

utterances.speaker: SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER, D-N.Y.
utterances.sentences: To watch what happens in the White House would make your jaw drop. I was prepared to give him a 35-page plan. We were interested. We are interested in doing infrastructure. It's clear the president isn't. But this was not a spontaneous move on the president's part. It was planned.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And the president wasn't having it. He fired right back tweeting, the Democrats are tearing the country apart. But of course, Pelosi has since doubled down on her cover-up comment and claims it could be an impeachable offense.  All right, Dana, it's pretty clear to the country that Nancy and Chuck cannot work with the president. So far they've shut down the government, no border security, no infrastructure, investigations. It's a mess.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.sentences: Right. So the Democrats -- I'm trying to think of like what is the good news that they could point to in January that they have cause, right? Is there anything that has gone their way? Not really, OK? And now, they might be able to spin a couple things. But they might say, well, the president's poll numbers are still down. However, the president could say, well, I might not be able to get a lot done with Congress, but the things I have done that are under my control, I've been able to execute on and look at our economy, look at all -- we have the list. We can go through the list. I think the think about her, Nancy Pelosi, is she's super strategic. We know she's very wise. She's very good at politics. She didn't just say cover-up as like an offhand remark. This was a deliberate intention because she's under the pressure from grassroots.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: She was forced to say that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's also is very -- it gets under his skin, right? She loves to get him riled up, so that then she can say, oh, my gosh. You would have not believed the reaction. It was just overwhelming and I have to pray for him. And --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But her caucus wants infrastructure and impeachment --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That is true. But what I also like about this idea is I'm just picturing it, they're in the cabinet room, the president walking in, not sitting down --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- like, yeah, this stuff is over. Like, we're not doing this. And if you think back to when his supporters would say in a primary election when he was beating all the Republicans, what do you like about him? And they would say, well, he tells it like it is. It was a charade to think one that infrastructure was going to get done anyway. They're so far apart. A 35-page plan doesn't work for anybody. Nobody needs a 35-page plan. He needs a one-page plan to see if they could do it. So that was a charade. It wasn't going to happen. The president is basically like, let's just stop pretending. That you just -- that you are here to help get me impeached, but to pretend like you were actually wanted to work on things. And he said, I'm not going to do it anymore.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, why would you negotiate, Greg, when somebody has a knife to your throat?

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.sentences: This was a great example of when politics clashes with business, all right? It went -- what Nancy and Chuck did was plan and it was political. And I would be pissed off, too. It'd be like Dana coming before “The Five” and just announcing that she burned my house down. Now let's go do “The Five.” You don't do that.  And so -- when you're in business, no one before a meeting would accuse you of being a criminal, right? But in politics, there is no such limitation. They'll call you a criminal -- a war criminal and then they'll have lunch with you. And then when they said, well, clearly he doesn't want infrastructure. How stupid do you think the American public is? He was pissed off because of what you did. It had -- he wants infrastructure. He's been doing infrastructure his entire life. I do love the fact that he brought visuals, that means, you know, he's incorporating Fox graphics into his display. And Trump's poll numbers might be down, but when you ask Americans what kind of job he's doing and if they are better off? They're way high. How stupid do you have to be to see how this plays out? Impeachment fails. Trump is a folk hero. Impeachment succeeds, he's a folk hero, and you have Pence as president and you have Trump going around. He's not going anywhere.   You're going to have two Republican presidents. And everybody who pushed the hysteria will be a laughing stock because they're not going to reelect -- they're not going to elect Bernie Sanders after this. You're going to have 75 million people who are pissed off and they're going to re-elect Pence. The point is -- no, the pendulum swings. The more you jump over, the more you push, the more they push back. And that's what you're going to see with Brexit. That's what you're seeing right now with France. People are going after him and it's just going to create more fans.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, what do you think happened today?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.sentences: I'm so amazed to listen because it seems to me Trump did a big stunt in which he didn't know how to pay for infrastructure. That's what's going on in Washington. Last time that he was engaged in a conversation with Democrats about infrastructure, he got in trouble with fellow Republicans who said, hey, hold on, Mr. President. We're not raising taxes. We're not talking about a gas tax. We're not talking about repealing any of the tax cuts that you put in place, unpopular as they may be.  But guess what? If you are serious about infrastructure and the president in his last meeting with the Democrats said $2 trillion, you have to find the money somewhere. The revenue has to come from somewhere. And he doesn't know where to get the money.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wait, Juan --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's the truth.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You buy that he sabotage the meeting because he didn't know where the money was coming from?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Right, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He doesn't care about where the money is coming from.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, somebody has to govern the country. And if you want --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, come on.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Let me finish.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Guess what? You talk about preplanned. What was preplanned was his Rose Garden ceremony before they even got to the White House. How do you think they have that sign out there?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, maybe that Pelosi was the one who miscalculated because she was force by her caucus to say something aggressive. She miscalculated, accused the president of a criminal cover-up, and now the American people don't have the infrastructure that they want.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Are you kidding me? She's not responsible -- first of all, what a crazy thing he said when he said nothing will get done until these investigations -- well, that means -- guess what, Mr. President? The investigations are not going to stop. So you're saying the country is not going to be governed --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We've had two years of investigations, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Bill Clinton was being impeach and he worked on the S Chip Bill in terms of helping young people --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And his approval numbers went up as he --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yeah. But this guy said, Dana, he's not going to do anything.

utterances.speaker: EMILY COMPAGNO, HOST
utterances.sentences: The Democrats are so -- the Democrats are so transparent that they are willing to sabotage their own purported interests or the interests of their constituents rather than give Trump an inch. Not even a victory, just an inch. And what I mean by that is it was so obvious that, yes, this is a charade. Yes, this was planned. Yes, this was strategy. Of course, it was Pelosi tossing that lit match on to the bundle of cinder that is Trump when she says there's a cover-up and has these buzz words. Of course, he's going to freak out.  So it was so transparent to people like us. And the worse part is that infrastructure is bipartisan. And the money is absolutely there when there's projected $3 trillion in audits uncovered in the government, in terms of like slashing spending. The money is absolutely there. That's not the issue. The issue is that these guys are putting the deal before themselves in terms of what it represents. Like if Schumer and Pelosi were actually interested in infrastructure, they wouldn't have pulled this stunt. And Schumer, it was like the Nicene Creed. We believe in this and we believe in this. Like the whole thing is such a farce from top to bottom.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So in other words, you think there's money -- you think there's money sitting there, but I don't think the president --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, it's not about money.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It is.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's not about money. They're accusing the president of covering up a crime that never happened.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The Russian interference never happened?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I love how he shifted that. He said Russian interference. He didn't say collusion. He already blew it. No, no, no, you have enough. You have enough, Juan. You have enough, Juan. I love the use of the phrase cover-up on the same day the investigation into the Virginia governor, Northam, who may or may not have been covered up in black face. That's the cover-up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, Michael Avenatti indicted for allegedly defrauding Stormy Daniels, breaking news up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Breaking news, brand new legal trouble for Michael Avenatti. Greg is ready for this one. The lawyer indicted this afternoon on fraud and identity theft charges involving his former client Stormy Daniels. Avenatti is accused of stealing almost $300,000 from her. The feds say Daniels was supposed to get that money from a book deal, but Avenatti instead diverted it to his own account and then used it on personal and business expenses.  Now he was also hit today with new charges tied to an alleged extortion plot against Nike. Also, Avenatti faces over 400 years in jail. And, Greg, I just don't think that's enough time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, I don't either. You know what I love about -- he said something like he wouldn't have been caught if he didn't bring attention to himself. So it's not about the crimes he committed but the exposure he brought to the crimes. That's like saying, you know, I shouldn't have worn that really bright shirt when I burned down the orphanage. It's not -- it's a crime. By the way, so he stole $300,000 from Stormy?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's a book deal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think I've said this before. In terms of career decisions, he has been able to make doing porn a lesser evil than hiring Michael Avenatti. It is so delicious to watch him go down because it's the media. It's actually not him. It's the media who indulged him because they loved how he delivered those talking points about Trump that they wanted so badly, whether it's Don Lemon or Chris Matthews or Stelter, who all -- they took him seriously when he was thinking about running for president. He was going to run against Trump. I still wish he would.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Emily --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: By the way, is he disbarred?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, that's actually what I'm going to ask her, is he disbarred? Is it true that judges look very unfavorably at lawyers who actually commit these kinds of crimes?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. He's not disbarred yet. And this point he's not technically convicted of anything, right? So that's --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That won't stop us.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's a detail.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Ethically in terms of the bars -- yeah, that's just a matter of time. What's crazy thing is how delusional he is. Like he keep saying, well, I'm looking forward to, you know, total exoneration by the jury, whatever the flake you're saying. Like, we all saw you toss that lighted match, bro. Like, you are clear -- it's just insane to me. And also, you know the charging documents they read like total drama. And it's shows what a character he is, right? He's yelling and angry and cussing and has all the quotes because so much of his extortion scheme -- remember, there's three different schemes that he's charged with in two different districts that it just reads like this complete law and order episode. And I guarantee they make an episode off this.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I should say, Juan, that Avenatti denied the allegations on twitter saying no money relating to Daniels were ever misappropriated or mishandled. She received millions of dollars with the legal services, and we've spent huge sums in expenses and she directly paid only $100 for all she received.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, I just -- I don't know the details. I mean, I'm told that it's not only Stormy Daniels, but there's some pro-basketball players that he was representing that he also is charged with having stolen money from them. And so, this -- it's building up like a long list. It's sort of, you know -- at some point, you've got to say, hmm, something is going on here. Not good for him. I would say it looks like people are just taking pleasure, especially President Trump supporters in his downfall and all these charges against him because --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He took pleasure in the whole Kavanaugh stuff. He deserves everything he gets.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think, in fact, in the Kavanaugh stuff, his actions turned out to damage the opponents of Kavanaugh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Of course.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So -- but I think his thing -- his big issue here is Stormy Daniels. And Stormy Daniels and the fact -- remember, in the previous segment the president said what cover-up? I would never do a cover-up. Well, we know that he was sending money to Stormy Daniels for a nondisclosure agreement and apparently trying to involve the kind of --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But that's not -- but remember in the A-block where we all talked about that -- that was all about collusion, not about Stormy Daniels.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, no, the Avenatti stuff was about Stormy Daniels.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I see. He also tried to go after Nike. That was --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, yeah, don't go after Nike.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Don't do that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They're big.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Just don't do it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm beginning to think that Trump and Stormy Daniels never had an affair. I mean, that's how bad it's gotten. I assume that he did it the whole time. And now the two lawyers who litigated it, Cohen and Avenatti, are both indicted.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's true.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And the two, you know, people that allegedly had affair they're fine. This is not just indictment of Avenatti. This is indictment of the media. Think about it. They can't vet a guy like this? They can vet Avenatti. They can't vet Russian collusion. They can't vet Smollett. The one job the media is supposed to be good at vetting and they can't do it. I read this article about him on Vanity Fair. His lawyers advised him against doing the Vanity Fair article. He did it anyway. Of course, he cried four times when he was giving the interview. Allegedly, he was abusive to bookers. Now, I was a booker. People that treat the talent well and that reign hell down on the bookers, they're an evil type of people. So CNN knew this guy was reigning hell on the bookers and they still booked him. And whenever the bookers tried to vet these new claims he was bringing, he said no and threw a tantrum. The guy is a rageaholic, an adrenaline junky, and apparently was spending the Stormy Daniels' money on dry cleaning. Who does that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: A dirty guy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, a dirty guy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He was laundering.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think we beat that horse to death. Good luck.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You just insulted a house.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That was a little sound bite.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, he's more like a rat, not a horse.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We just beat that rat --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Feel free to beat the rat.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right, up next, ESPN now sticking to sports after backlash for being, guess what, too political.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: A couple of big companies finally ditching politics and getting back to what they do best. After years of anchors bashing Trump, ESPN's president says he's doing everything to just focus on sports. Quote, without question, our data tells us our fans do not want us to cover politics. Here are a few examples of why.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I think it was classless on the part of the President of the United States.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's disgraceful. It was classless. It was wrong to do. He could do better than that.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Do you still stand by what you said, and do you think that President Trump supporters are white supremacists?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I still stand by what I said. I don't think that his supporters are white supremacists.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: What is really going on in this country right now is the question. Is the president above the law? Or do we have a king? And reasonable people all agree the answer is no to both those questions.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: And Dunkin' Donuts is calling out rival Starbucks for pushing political agendas. A top executive reportedly saying, quote, we aren't gonna put stuff on our cups to start conversation. We don't want to engage you in political conversations. We want to get you in and out of our store in seconds. It's donuts and ice cream. Just be happy. All right. So, Greg --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: -- I feel like sports is supposed to be a unifier. It's supposed to be the escape.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: So this completely makes sense.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Someone should write a song about this. Maybe call it shut up about politics. Hey, OK. Politics was invented at its own stand-alone process to mitigate disputes without revolutions or violence. That's what politics was for. It was a cultural invention not meant for anything but within its political realm. So when you -- so for some reason it's been injected when the left made the politics personal, that was their slogan in the 70s and 80s, politics was able to spread into other areas like sports, music and comedy. It's like injecting yoga into drag racing. And it's open the gates to this infection. And there's a lot of consequence. People are now obsessed with identity politics instead of their own individuality. So now you're not a person, you're just a box. You know, you're a part of something. You're not you on campus if you look at literature, if you look at speeches or instructions. Things -- politics -- because it's seen as a tool. These things are seen as unfeasibly because they don't fit into the political package. And then entertainment becomes divisive to your point. See how crappy -- Jim Carrey's actual acting ability has become as his devoted his time to hateful politics. Look at De Niro who I've said yesterday, I absolutely adored until I heard him open his mouth for once without a script. And it's just like destroying to see this -- you know -- wherever it goes, it hurts. Imagine if “The Five” if we just decided to play like sand volleyball here for an hour. We don't do sports for a reason.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I want Emily on my team.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: And I feel like, Dana, part of it is that -- which is what you're kind of alluding to that viewers don't want to be surprised, right? They tune, they want to have expectations and sort of the lame, right? So it's part of it that it was like --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, it's like you tune in to certain things. And one of the great things about cable is that they gave you specific shows. Like people -- some people like to watch Bravos. Some people like Home and Garden TV. Some people watch Fox News all day long. Some people love their sports. And also you could flip around. It's also true virtue about politics infecting women's magazines.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: TiVo --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- it killed it. Killed TiVo. I know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And team sports politics like bringing sports into politics has also been unattractive and not good. The thing that's been very interesting though over the last few years is that Fox News has been very impressed with my sports commentary.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And has asked me to do more of it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, I don't believe that for a second.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: And, Jesse, a part of this I think is that anchors, you know, that brand is bigger than themselves in that moment, right? So you were saying, they're putting themselves above the brand. And also I think -- and now I'm not really asking a question.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: I feel like there's a way to charge the population with being engaged. Like politics is cool. And, yes, like be involved. But by being apolitical in terms of the actual issues, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't know what the question was. But --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Agree with me, right?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, you're right, kid.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The CEO had a massive cocaine problem and he got extorted by his dealer. And he let go of the ship for many, many years. And this was happening just as people were cutting their cable. They did not become the profit machine like they were supposed to for Disney. And they had to lay off hundreds and hundreds of people. The guy, skipper, who I said had a massive cocaine problem had to abruptly resign. Also, stood up Bob Iger, the CEO of Disney, while he was waiting for him at -- in the jet, on the runway after the ESPY's. So he was on -- it was really bad. You don't do that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He blamed it on the dealer though.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's right. So all of these things are coalescing at the same time. They're not making as much money. And he's letting these anchors like Jemele Hill have a total free ride. She can go on twitter, call the President of the United States a white supremacist, and then go do Sports Center? Are you kidding me? The audience cannot read that on twitter and then watch her face on TV doing the top ten that week. They can't conceptualize it. They lost track of their audience. Their audience is predominantly white males who probably support President Trump, and they let that audience totally go. And now they have to get back to basics. And that's what people want.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: So since the new president has come in, as Jesse was saying, the revenue is up 6 percent for ESPN. So, the statistics are kind of revealing exactly this, right. Do you agree?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, I think this guy--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He always leads the witness. It's very funny.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think this new guy is simply being very politically correct. Right. He's simply saying, I'd rather not talk about politics. But the reality is, I disagree with Greg so strongly. I mean you go back to Jack Johnson, that's politics, when you need a great white hope. You go back to Jesse Owens against Adolf Hitler. Hey America, said you know what this is proof, your racial--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's not politics. This is morality.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: This is politics. This is Ali and Vietnam and come forward to Nike and Colin Kaepernick. If you don't--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Not in the same breath.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Because sports right now is a part of our American culture it's a leading indicator of who we are and where we're going.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But you have to cover it in a balanced way and not through insult to the President of the United States.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's fine. It's the same thing with Dunkin Donuts which we mentioned at the top. I don't think Dunkin Donuts cares anything about politics either conservative or liberal. What they care about selling coffee. They see that Howard Schultz, the Head of Starbucks is running for President and they're saying, hey, we're not running for anything come buy our coffee. That's what they care about. And if you want to truly cover sports in America, you have to realize hey, half of the Boston Red Sox who are black and Latino won't even go near the Trump White House.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But you know what, Rachel Maddow covering sports for you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

Monday night, I took a five-hour driving class, a mandatory step before the road test. Here's my lesson. Once you get a driver's license, you become a trial lawyers dream. You hit someone, someone hits you, your whole life is ruined. There are also countless ways to land in jail. For example, I had no idea, a trunk isn't considered a passenger seat. Now since I took a similar course when I was 16, this class revealed to me how age changes your assessment of risks. When you're young, death seem so far away. Not around the corner. It's why you speed and show off. You think you're impervious to dumb ideas like burning rubber, running a stop sign or supporting a socialist. It's biology, your brain isn't fully developed. So, the many risks that you enter your life once you drive at 16 seem nonexistent. Now decades later hearing the same instruction, it's absolutely terrifying. You're older, you have more to lose, your brains matured, and you understand how arbitrary life is and how far out of control everything is no matter how careful you are the other guy wielding a two-ton weapon with a gas pedal might not be. 40,000 people die each year in accidents. That's a small town every 12 months with texting teens, distracted adults and stupid drunks. It should be higher. It's why I love self-driving cars, which can wipe out all fatalities due to human error. If you feel differently sit through one driver's ed class at my age and you will never drive again. I learned a lot of things here Emily. You own a muscle car; you must love to drive. I love to drive, but I think about all the risks and I don't want to.

utterances.utterance: -- like, yeah, this stuff is over. Like, we're not doing this. And if you think back to when his supporters would say in a primary election when he was beating all the Republicans, what do you like about him? And they would say, well, he tells it like it is. It was a charade to think one that infrastructure was going to get done anyway. They're so far apart. A 35-page plan doesn't work for anybody. Nobody needs a 35-page plan. He needs a one-page plan to see if they could do it. So that was a charade. It wasn't going to happen. The president is basically like, let's just stop pretending. That you just -- that you are here to help get me impeached, but to pretend like you were actually wanted to work on things. And he said, I'm not going to do it anymore.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, why would you negotiate, Greg, when somebody has a knife to your throat?

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.utterance: This was a great example of when politics clashes with business, all right? It went -- what Nancy and Chuck did was plan and it was political. And I would be pissed off, too. It'd be like Dana coming before “The Five” and just announcing that she burned my house down. Now let's go do “The Five.” You don't do that. And so -- when you're in business, no one before a meeting would accuse you of being a criminal, right? But in politics, there is no such limitation. They'll call you a criminal -- a war criminal and then they'll have lunch with you. And then when they said, well, clearly he doesn't want infrastructure. How stupid do you think the American public is? He was pissed off because of what you did. It had -- he wants infrastructure. He's been doing infrastructure his entire life. I do love the fact that he brought visuals, that means, you know, he's incorporating Fox graphics into his display. And Trump's poll numbers might be down, but when you ask Americans what kind of job he's doing and if they are better off? They're way high. How stupid do you have to be to see how this plays out? Impeachment fails. Trump is a folk hero. Impeachment succeeds, he's a folk hero, and you have Pence as president and you have Trump going around. He's not going anywhere. You're going to have two Republican presidents. And everybody who pushed the hysteria will be a laughing stock because they're not going to reelect -- they're not going to elect Bernie Sanders after this. You're going to have 75 million people who are pissed off and they're going to re-elect Pence. The point is -- no, the pendulum swings. The more you jump over, the more you push, the more they push back. And that's what you're going to see with Brexit. That's what you're seeing right now with France. People are going after him and it's just going to create more fans.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, what do you think happened today?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.utterance: I'm so amazed to listen because it seems to me Trump did a big stunt in which he didn't know how to pay for infrastructure. That's what's going on in Washington. Last time that he was engaged in a conversation with Democrats about infrastructure, he got in trouble with fellow Republicans who said, hey, hold on, Mr. President. We're not raising taxes. We're not talking about a gas tax. We're not talking about repealing any of the tax cuts that you put in place, unpopular as they may be. But guess what? If you are serious about infrastructure and the president in his last meeting with the Democrats said $2 trillion, you have to find the money somewhere. The revenue has to come from somewhere. And he doesn't know where to get the money.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wait, Juan --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's the truth.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You buy that he sabotage the meeting because he didn't know where the money was coming from?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He doesn't care about where the money is coming from.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, somebody has to govern the country. And if you want --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, come on.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me finish.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Guess what? You talk about preplanned. What was preplanned was his Rose Garden ceremony before they even got to the White House. How do you think they have that sign out there?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, maybe that Pelosi was the one who miscalculated because she was force by her caucus to say something aggressive. She miscalculated, accused the president of a criminal cover-up, and now the American people don't have the infrastructure that they want.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Are you kidding me? She's not responsible -- first of all, what a crazy thing he said when he said nothing will get done until these investigations -- well, that means -- guess what, Mr. President? The investigations are not going to stop. So you're saying the country is not going to be governed --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We've had two years of investigations, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Bill Clinton was being impeach and he worked on the S Chip Bill in terms of helping young people --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And his approval numbers went up as he --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. But this guy said, Dana, he's not going to do anything.

utterances.speaker: EMILY COMPAGNO, HOST
utterances.utterance: The Democrats are so -- the Democrats are so transparent that they are willing to sabotage their own purported interests or the interests of their constituents rather than give Trump an inch. Not even a victory, just an inch. And what I mean by that is it was so obvious that, yes, this is a charade. Yes, this was planned. Yes, this was strategy. Of course, it was Pelosi tossing that lit match on to the bundle of cinder that is Trump when she says there's a cover-up and has these buzz words. Of course, he's going to freak out. So it was so transparent to people like us. And the worse part is that infrastructure is bipartisan. And the money is absolutely there when there's projected $3 trillion in audits uncovered in the government, in terms of like slashing spending. The money is absolutely there. That's not the issue. The issue is that these guys are putting the deal before themselves in terms of what it represents. Like if Schumer and Pelosi were actually interested in infrastructure, they wouldn't have pulled this stunt. And Schumer, it was like the Nicene Creed. We believe in this and we believe in this. Like the whole thing is such a farce from top to bottom.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So in other words, you think there's money -- you think there's money sitting there, but I don't think the president --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, it's not about money.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It is.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's not about money. They're accusing the president of covering up a crime that never happened.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The Russian interference never happened?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I love how he shifted that. He said Russian interference. He didn't say collusion. He already blew it. No, no, no, you have enough. You have enough, Juan. You have enough, Juan. I love the use of the phrase cover-up on the same day the investigation into the Virginia governor, Northam, who may or may not have been covered up in black face. That's the cover-up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, Michael Avenatti indicted for allegedly defrauding Stormy Daniels, breaking news up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Breaking news, brand new legal trouble for Michael Avenatti. Greg is ready for this one. The lawyer indicted this afternoon on fraud and identity theft charges involving his former client Stormy Daniels. Avenatti is accused of stealing almost $300,000 from her. The feds say Daniels was supposed to get that money from a book deal, but Avenatti instead diverted it to his own account and then used it on personal and business expenses. Now he was also hit today with new charges tied to an alleged extortion plot against Nike. Also, Avenatti faces over 400 years in jail. And, Greg, I just don't think that's enough time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I don't either. You know what I love about -- he said something like he wouldn't have been caught if he didn't bring attention to himself. So it's not about the crimes he committed but the exposure he brought to the crimes. That's like saying, you know, I shouldn't have worn that really bright shirt when I burned down the orphanage. It's not -- it's a crime. By the way, so he stole $300,000 from Stormy?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's a book deal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think I've said this before. In terms of career decisions, he has been able to make doing porn a lesser evil than hiring Michael Avenatti. It is so delicious to watch him go down because it's the media. It's actually not him. It's the media who indulged him because they loved how he delivered those talking points about Trump that they wanted so badly, whether it's Don Lemon or Chris Matthews or Stelter, who all -- they took him seriously when he was thinking about running for president. He was going to run against Trump. I still wish he would.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Emily --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: By the way, is he disbarred?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, that's actually what I'm going to ask her, is he disbarred? Is it true that judges look very unfavorably at lawyers who actually commit these kinds of crimes?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Absolutely. He's not disbarred yet. And this point he's not technically convicted of anything, right? So that's --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That won't stop us.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's a detail.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Ethically in terms of the bars -- yeah, that's just a matter of time. What's crazy thing is how delusional he is. Like he keep saying, well, I'm looking forward to, you know, total exoneration by the jury, whatever the flake you're saying. Like, we all saw you toss that lighted match, bro. Like, you are clear -- it's just insane to me. And also, you know the charging documents they read like total drama. And it's shows what a character he is, right? He's yelling and angry and cussing and has all the quotes because so much of his extortion scheme -- remember, there's three different schemes that he's charged with in two different districts that it just reads like this complete law and order episode. And I guarantee they make an episode off this.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I should say, Juan, that Avenatti denied the allegations on twitter saying no money relating to Daniels were ever misappropriated or mishandled. She received millions of dollars with the legal services, and we've spent huge sums in expenses and she directly paid only $100 for all she received.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, I just -- I don't know the details. I mean, I'm told that it's not only Stormy Daniels, but there's some pro-basketball players that he was representing that he also is charged with having stolen money from them. And so, this -- it's building up like a long list. It's sort of, you know -- at some point, you've got to say, hmm, something is going on here. Not good for him. I would say it looks like people are just taking pleasure, especially President Trump supporters in his downfall and all these charges against him because --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He took pleasure in the whole Kavanaugh stuff. He deserves everything he gets.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think, in fact, in the Kavanaugh stuff, his actions turned out to damage the opponents of Kavanaugh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Of course.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So -- but I think his thing -- his big issue here is Stormy Daniels. And Stormy Daniels and the fact -- remember, in the previous segment the president said what cover-up? I would never do a cover-up. Well, we know that he was sending money to Stormy Daniels for a nondisclosure agreement and apparently trying to involve the kind of --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But that's not -- but remember in the A-block where we all talked about that -- that was all about collusion, not about Stormy Daniels.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, the Avenatti stuff was about Stormy Daniels.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I see. He also tried to go after Nike. That was --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, yeah, don't go after Nike.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Don't do that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They're big.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Just don't do it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm beginning to think that Trump and Stormy Daniels never had an affair. I mean, that's how bad it's gotten. I assume that he did it the whole time. And now the two lawyers who litigated it, Cohen and Avenatti, are both indicted.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And the two, you know, people that allegedly had affair they're fine. This is not just indictment of Avenatti. This is indictment of the media. Think about it. They can't vet a guy like this? They can vet Avenatti. They can't vet Russian collusion. They can't vet Smollett. The one job the media is supposed to be good at vetting and they can't do it. I read this article about him on Vanity Fair. His lawyers advised him against doing the Vanity Fair article. He did it anyway. Of course, he cried four times when he was giving the interview. Allegedly, he was abusive to bookers. Now, I was a booker. People that treat the talent well and that reign hell down on the bookers, they're an evil type of people. So CNN knew this guy was reigning hell on the bookers and they still booked him. And whenever the bookers tried to vet these new claims he was bringing, he said no and threw a tantrum. The guy is a rageaholic, an adrenaline junky, and apparently was spending the Stormy Daniels' money on dry cleaning. Who does that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A dirty guy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, a dirty guy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He was laundering.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think we beat that horse to death. Good luck.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You just insulted a house.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That was a little sound bite.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, he's more like a rat, not a horse.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We just beat that rat --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Feel free to beat the rat.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, up next, ESPN now sticking to sports after backlash for being, guess what, too political.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: A couple of big companies finally ditching politics and getting back to what they do best. After years of anchors bashing Trump, ESPN's president says he's doing everything to just focus on sports. Quote, without question, our data tells us our fans do not want us to cover politics. Here are a few examples of why.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I think it was classless on the part of the President of the United States.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It's disgraceful. It was classless. It was wrong to do. He could do better than that.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Do you still stand by what you said, and do you think that President Trump supporters are white supremacists?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: I still stand by what I said. I don't think that his supporters are white supremacists.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: What is really going on in this country right now is the question. Is the president above the law? Or do we have a king? And reasonable people all agree the answer is no to both those questions.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: And Dunkin' Donuts is calling out rival Starbucks for pushing political agendas. A top executive reportedly saying, quote, we aren't gonna put stuff on our cups to start conversation. We don't want to engage you in political conversations. We want to get you in and out of our store in seconds. It's donuts and ice cream. Just be happy. All right. So, Greg --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: -- I feel like sports is supposed to be a unifier. It's supposed to be the escape.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: So this completely makes sense.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Someone should write a song about this. Maybe call it shut up about politics. Hey, OK. Politics was invented at its own stand-alone process to mitigate disputes without revolutions or violence. That's what politics was for. It was a cultural invention not meant for anything but within its political realm. So when you -- so for some reason it's been injected when the left made the politics personal, that was their slogan in the 70s and 80s, politics was able to spread into other areas like sports, music and comedy. It's like injecting yoga into drag racing. And it's open the gates to this infection. And there's a lot of consequence. People are now obsessed with identity politics instead of their own individuality. So now you're not a person, you're just a box. You know, you're a part of something. You're not you on campus if you look at literature, if you look at speeches or instructions. Things -- politics -- because it's seen as a tool. These things are seen as unfeasibly because they don't fit into the political package. And then entertainment becomes divisive to your point. See how crappy -- Jim Carrey's actual acting ability has become as his devoted his time to hateful politics. Look at De Niro who I've said yesterday, I absolutely adored until I heard him open his mouth for once without a script. And it's just like destroying to see this -- you know -- wherever it goes, it hurts. Imagine if “The Five” if we just decided to play like sand volleyball here for an hour. We don't do sports for a reason.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I want Emily on my team.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: And I feel like, Dana, part of it is that -- which is what you're kind of alluding to that viewers don't want to be surprised, right? They tune, they want to have expectations and sort of the lame, right? So it's part of it that it was like --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, it's like you tune in to certain things. And one of the great things about cable is that they gave you specific shows. Like people -- some people like to watch Bravos. Some people like Home and Garden TV. Some people watch Fox News all day long. Some people love their sports. And also you could flip around. It's also true virtue about politics infecting women's magazines.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: TiVo --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- it killed it. Killed TiVo. I know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And team sports politics like bringing sports into politics has also been unattractive and not good. The thing that's been very interesting though over the last few years is that Fox News has been very impressed with my sports commentary.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And has asked me to do more of it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I don't believe that for a second.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: And, Jesse, a part of this I think is that anchors, you know, that brand is bigger than themselves in that moment, right? So you were saying, they're putting themselves above the brand. And also I think -- and now I'm not really asking a question.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: I feel like there's a way to charge the population with being engaged. Like politics is cool. And, yes, like be involved. But by being apolitical in terms of the actual issues, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't know what the question was. But --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Agree with me, right?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, you're right, kid.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The CEO had a massive cocaine problem and he got extorted by his dealer. And he let go of the ship for many, many years. And this was happening just as people were cutting their cable. They did not become the profit machine like they were supposed to for Disney. And they had to lay off hundreds and hundreds of people. The guy, skipper, who I said had a massive cocaine problem had to abruptly resign. Also, stood up Bob Iger, the CEO of Disney, while he was waiting for him at -- in the jet, on the runway after the ESPY's. So he was on -- it was really bad. You don't do that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He blamed it on the dealer though.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. So all of these things are coalescing at the same time. They're not making as much money. And he's letting these anchors like Jemele Hill have a total free ride. She can go on twitter, call the President of the United States a white supremacist, and then go do Sports Center? Are you kidding me? The audience cannot read that on twitter and then watch her face on TV doing the top ten that week. They can't conceptualize it. They lost track of their audience. Their audience is predominantly white males who probably support President Trump, and they let that audience totally go. And now they have to get back to basics. And that's what people want.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: So since the new president has come in, as Jesse was saying, the revenue is up 6 percent for ESPN. So, the statistics are kind of revealing exactly this, right. Do you agree?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, I think this guy--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He always leads the witness. It's very funny.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think this new guy is simply being very politically correct. Right. He's simply saying, I'd rather not talk about politics. But the reality is, I disagree with Greg so strongly. I mean you go back to Jack Johnson, that's politics, when you need a great white hope. You go back to Jesse Owens against Adolf Hitler. Hey America, said you know what this is proof, your racial--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's not politics. This is morality.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is politics. This is Ali and Vietnam and come forward to Nike and Colin Kaepernick. If you don't--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Not in the same breath.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because sports right now is a part of our American culture it's a leading indicator of who we are and where we're going.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But you have to cover it in a balanced way and not through insult to the President of the United States.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's fine. It's the same thing with Dunkin Donuts which we mentioned at the top. I don't think Dunkin Donuts cares anything about politics either conservative or liberal. What they care about selling coffee. They see that Howard Schultz, the Head of Starbucks is running for President and they're saying, hey, we're not running for anything come buy our coffee. That's what they care about. And if you want to truly cover sports in America, you have to realize hey, half of the Boston Red Sox who are black and Latino won't even go near the Trump White House.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But you know what, Rachel Maddow covering sports for you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, what I'm saying, but you can't say to people who are smart and who are in the world of sports, we don't want to ever hear what you think.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, just do it respectfully.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: In other words, be pro-Trump.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, just do it in a balanced way.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Also, with those businesses that's elective, you can choose to get your coffee at Dunkin versus Starbucks. You know that Tom - what's that ice cream, Ben & Jerry's, a super political right, but for sports you can't choose who's covering it. You can't choose--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You can click over to Fox Sports Juan; they do a great job.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes. OK. We have to go. Up next. Watch.

utterances.speaker: REP. KATIE PORTER, D-CALIF.
utterances.utterance: Do you know what an REO is?

utterances.speaker: BEN CARSON, SECRETARY OF HOUSING AND URBAN DEVELOPMENT
utterances.utterance: An Oreo.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.utterance: No, not an Oreo. An REO.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Ben Carson's Oreo gaffe and other cringe worthy political moments. Next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. We've had some cringeworthy political moments this week and it's not even over. First up, HUD Secretary Ben Carson apparently getting a real estate term mixed up with a cookie during a Capitol Hill hearing. Watch.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.utterance: I'd also like you to get back to me if you don't mind to explain the disparity in REO rates. Do you know what an REO is?

utterances.speaker: CARSON
utterances.utterance: An Oreo.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.utterance: No, not an Oreo. An REO.

utterances.speaker: CARSON
utterances.utterance: Real estate.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.utterance: What's the O stand for?

utterances.speaker: CARSON
utterances.utterance: Organization.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.utterance: Owned, real estate owned.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Ben Carson's responding by saying of course he knows what it means. An Oreo, just having some fun joking that REO is actually an acronym for really excellent Oreo. Let me just say before anybody gets any excitement, my son works for Ben Carson. Emily, what do you make of Ben Carson's misstep here?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: I feel bad for him because as he explained after he totally knows what it is, it just was kind of a mistake in that moment and I feel like that's what happens to me when I don't hear someone correctly. I'm like what's that. And then they explain that and I'm like no, I know what that means. I just didn't hear you. And then also, if those genders had been reversed or if that had been a person of color as the receiving end of that there would be a complete pandemonium, that level of condescension to me is absolutely unacceptable.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Jesse, do you think race because people say an Oreo is like a black person, does that have anything to do with this?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I didn't see race here. This was a missed opportunity for a food court. We should have Oreos on set, but that's fine. This is the kind of scandal you want. You want a scandal involving a cookie. Like Dana, her biggest scandal involved queso. So, those are the kind of scandals you want. You don't want one with you know an affair or a dead body. This is perfect for Ben Carson. But let's remember, he's a brilliant man. He separates conjoined twins to think that this guy is not smart.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's how he separates Oreos, it goes like this.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Is that right, good. OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They all live.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
